alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect.

Heavy snow expected beginning Monday morning.

Hazards:
Locally heavy snowfall with total accumulations of 5 to 10 cm.
Peak snowfall rates of 3 to 5 cm per hour.
Reduced visibility at times in heavy snow.
Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h Monday night.

Timing:
Late Monday morning through Monday afternoon for the initial band of heavy snow.
Monday evening through Monday night for the lake effect flurries, strong winds and local blowing snow.

Discussion:
An area of heavy snow will push through the region Monday. The majority of snow will fall within a few hours. By Monday evening, strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h and lake effect flurries will develop, resulting in reduced visibility at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winds and flurries will weaken early Tuesday morning.

###

Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas.

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect.

Heavy snow expected late Monday.

Hazards:
Locally heavy snowfall with total accumulations of 5 to 15 cm.
Peak snowfall rates of 3 to 5 cm per hour.
Reduced visibility at times in heavy snow.
Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h Monday night.

Timing:
Monday afternoon through Monday evening for the heavy snow.
Monday night into Tuesday morning for the strong winds and local blowing snow.

Discussion:
An area of heavy snow will move through the region Monday. Precipitation may initially begin as rain but will quickly turn to heavy snow as temperatures fall in the wake of a strong cold front. The snow will taper off from west to east Monday night through Tuesday morning. In addition to the snow, strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will also develop Monday night. Reduced visibility in blowing snow can be expected at times, particularly over exposed areas.

###

Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas.

Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect.

What:
Snow, at times heavy. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm.
Peak snowfall rates of 2 to 4 cm per hour.
Reduced visibility in snow and local blowing snow.

When:
Continuing through this morning.

Additional information:
Snow is expected to taper to flurries from west to east through late this morning.

In addition, northerly winds will intensify this morning with gusts up to 60 km/h resulting in local blowing snow.

###

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:

What:

alerts.headline: snowfall warning in effect
alerts.description:
Heavy snow followed by strong winds and local blowing snow.

What:
Snow, at times heavy. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm.
Peak snowfall rates of 3 to 5 cm per hour.
Reduced visibility in snow and local blowing snow.

When:
This morning through Tuesday morning.

Additional information:
Snow will begin for the Sudbury area early this morning before advancing eastward into central Ontario by this afternoon. Snow is expected to taper to flurries from west to east overnight into Tuesday morning.

In addition, northerly winds will intensify this afternoon over northeastern Ontario and over central Ontario tonight with gusts up to 60 km/h. The combination of these strong wind gusts and fresh snowfall may lead to localized reduced visibility in blowing snow.

###

Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect for this afternoon and tonight.

What:
Locally heavy snowfall with total accumulations of 5 to 15 cm.
Peak snowfall rates of 2 to 4 cm per hour possible.
Reduced visibility at times in heavy snow.
Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h tonight.

When:
Heavy snow is expected to impact areas near Georgian Bay early this afternoon, progressing eastwards through the day, reaching Barry's Bay and Petawawa by this evening.
Tonight into Tuesday morning for the strong winds and local blowing snow.

Additional information:
For some areas precipitation may initially begin as rain but will quickly transition to heavy snow as temperatures fall in the wake of a strong cold front. The snow will taper off from west to east late tonight through Tuesday morning

In addition to the snow, strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will also develop tonight. Reduced visibility in blowing snow can be expected at times, particularly over exposed areas.

###

Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

affected_areas.area_description: Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park
Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect for today through Tuesday morning.

What:
Locally heavy snowfall with total accumulations of 5 to 10 cm.
Reduced visibility at times in heavy snow and local blowing snow.
Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h Monday night.

When:
Late this morning or this afternoon for the initial band of heavy snow. 
Tonight into Tuesday morning for the strong winds, lake effect snow and local blowing snow.

Additional information:
A fast moving band of snow mixed with rain is forecast to move across the area today. As temperatures rapidly fall late this morning or this afternoon this band of rain mixed with snow will transition to a brief period of heavy snow. A quick 5 cm of snowfall is possible. 

By this evening, strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h and lake effect flurries will develop, resulting in reduced visibility at times in heavy snow and local blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. Lake effect snow amounts are expected to be near 5 cm. Winds will ease and flurries will slowly weaken Tuesday.

###

Motorists should expect hazardous winter driving conditions and adjust travel plans accordingly. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

affected_areas.area_description: Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County
Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect for tonight.

What:
Reduced visibility in heavy snow.
Snowfall amounts 3 to 5 cm.

When:
Beginning this evening and continuing after midnight.

Additional information:
A low pressure system is expected to bring a brief period of heavy snow to the area beginning this evening. The snow may be mixed with rain at times, especially for areas near the St. Lawrence river.

By Tuesday morning there may be another round of snow, together with northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h giving reduced visibility in snow and local blowing snow. Snowfall amounts for Tuesday are expected to be near 5 cm.

###

Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow.

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Take extra care when walking or driving in affected areas. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

alerts.headline: weather advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Winter weather travel advisory in effect for tonight and Tuesday.

What:
Heavy snowfall with total accumulations of 5 to 15 cm.
Reduced visibility in heavy snow and local blowing snow.

When:
Beginning late this evening and ending Tuesday afternoon.

Additional information:
A low pressure system is expected to bring heavy snow to the area beginning late this evening. Heavy snow will taper to light Tuesday morning before ending in the afternoon. Northwesterly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will develop Tuesday morning, resulting in reduced visibility in snow and local blowing snow.

###

For road conditions and other traveller information from the Ministry of Transportation, visit https://www.ontario.ca/511, https://www.twitter.com/511Ontario, or call 5-1-1.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.
